newsitem.title: USA: US blue chips stage late rally to close higher.
newsitem.headline: US blue chips stage late rally to close higher.

text.p: U.S. blue chips closed higher on Tuesday, shaking off an extended sell-off in the technology sector to rally sharply in the final minutes of the session.
The Dow industrials rose 52 points to close unofficially at 6858, with all the gains coming in a program-dominated last half-hour of trading.
The late rally saw funds flock to many of the selected large cap names that have driven the market higher in recent months. Oil shares in particular found support after a weak performance on Monday.
Chevron Corp, Exxon Corp and Texaco Inc were all among the Dow's strongest performers.
But the market's real test of confidence took place among technology stocks, which faced stiff selling pressure most of the day.
Late in the day, however, some top names in the sector, notably Intel Corp, finally began to rise, and traders said the buying interest seemed to spark a rapid-fire turnaround by large caps.
"A lot of people were watching Intel today," said Mike Rothberg, director of portfolio trading at Cantor Fitzgerald.
Intel is considered a tech bellwether, and many analysts use the stock to gauge investor sentiment toward the sector.
Early on, that was bad news for the market, because Intel fell below a key level at 150 and then "dropped like a stone" to 146-1/2, he said. But suddenly, the tide turned.

"Buyers seemed to step in at 146 for Intel, and it looked like that flushed out buyers for other large-cap stocks," Rothberg said. "Before long, we saw buy programs starting to kick in, and those really helped us at the end."
The late surge saw other top-tier tech companies such as Microsoft Corp and International Business Machines Corp reverse earlier losses.

By the end, Intel finished at 151-3/4, up 1/8 for the day, while Microsoft rose 3/4 to 98-1/2, recouping losses that took it as low as 95-1/8. IBM gained 2-1/2 to 145-1/4 after falling as low as 141-1/8.
Despite the rebound, investors clearly remained leery of smaller-cap tech stocks as well as shares in companies whose growth prospects appeared to be in doubt.

Motorola Inc was one such stock, falling four points to 63-1/2 after Swedish cellular telephone competitor LM Ericsson said it expected continued pressure on prices of its telecommunications products in 1997.
Motorola made similar comments just a month ago, but even so, investors beat a hasty retreat from the group.
"With the market as nervous as it is, stocks are getting knocked down every time there's bad news," said Barbara Marcin, vice president at Citibank Global Asset Management.
"For companies trading at very high price-to-earnings ratios, taking even a little off the earnings can really do a lot of damage," she said.
Nasdaq-listed shares in Ericsson fell 1-7/8 to 32-5/8 and shares in Finnish company Nokia AB fell 1-1/2 to 65-3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Centennial Technologies Inc failed to open for trading on the NYSE after the company announced it had dismissed several top executives and was examining past earnings reports for possible misstatements.
The shares, which closed on Monday at 16-1/2, have fallen steadily since December 11, 1996, when they closed at 55-1/2.
The Nasdaq Composite fell 3.83 to 1331.51.
The S&P 500 index rose 4.16 to 789.59, a record.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
